questionText: The Kursk was conducting a naval exercise when it sunk.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: One of Russia's largest submarines, the Kursk was commissioned in 1996 and carried a crew of 118.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: 15 vessels and warships were involved in the search for the sunken Kursk.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Russia turned down a French offer of help and Germany's offer of medical specialists.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The Russians confirmed all aboard were dead on the August 21, 2000.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Putin vowed to retrieve the bodies of the crew and the vessel itself.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Plans were made for an unnamed Norwegian company to begin the body retrieval operation on October 10, 2000.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The Russian submarine Kursk is an atomic powered submarine.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: The Kursk could hold a crew of 118.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: Russia refused help from France and Germany after the Kursk sank.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: Russia asked for help from Britain and Norway in the form of a rescue submarine and divers.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: The crew of the Kursk was confirmed dead on August 21, 2000.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: According to the United States, the Kursk sank because a torpedo misfired triggering a massive explosion.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: Russia is anticipating that it will cost $45 million to raise the Kursk.
author: A1DABMXVWWL0TR

questionText: The Kursk was sunk in August 12, 2000 in the Barents Sea.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: The Kursk was sunk during a Russian naval exercise.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: The Kursk was commissioned in 1996 in Russia.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: The Kursk was able to carry 118 crew members.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: Rescue efforts were suspended after one day of searching for the crew.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: Russia turned away medical specialist help from France and Germany.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: Officials from the United States think that one of the torpedoes on the Kursk misfired and caused an explosion.
author: A3U21PUMQ6NGT2

questionText: On August 19, 2000, a Russian nuclear submarine sank to the bottom of the Barents Sea.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The submarine that sunk in 2000 had 118 men aboard.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The ship's nuclear reactor had been switched off.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Russian navy rescue efforts were hampered by near zero visibility at the 450 feet depth where the vessel was trapped.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: A British mini-submarine was unable to dock with an escape hatch.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: A Russian nuclear submarine with 118 men aboard sank to the bottom of the Barents Sea.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: The ship was reported not to be carrying nuclear weapons.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: Examination with deep-water apparatus indicated it could have been shattered by a blast in its bow.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: Repeated attempts to dock with an escape hatch failed.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: Norwegian divers descended with video equipment, surveyed the damage, and ultimately opened an inner hatch.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: US sonar and other technical sources clearly provided no evidence of a collision.
author: A38OPVI04AH4JG

questionText: A Russian nuclear submarine sank on August 19, 2000.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: There were 118 men on the submarine when it sank.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: The submarine was on a training mission in the Barents Sea.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: Russian navy rescue efforts were complicated by strong underwater currents and near zero visibility.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: The condition of the crew could not be determined.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: Efforts to hook air and fuel lines failed.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: The Russians signed a contract with Dutch and Belgian companies to retrieve the submarine.
author: A2NGMLBFZ3YQP5

questionText: Russian submarine Kursk sank on August 12, 2000.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: Russian rescue attempts of the people aboard the Kursk did not begin until August 15.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: On Aug 18 the first Russian rescue capsule reached the Kursk's escape hatch.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: The crew of the Kursk submarine were officially announced dead.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: President Putin remained on vacation until Aug 19.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: Norwegian divers opened hatches to Kursk's flooded ninth compartment.
author: A3CWW9DIL73I14

questionText: The first announcement about Kursk was made on August 14.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: The first Russian rescue capsule reached Kursk on August 18.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: President Putin stayed on his vacation from August 19 to August 21.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: The escape hatch for Kursk was too badly damaged and the mini submarine could not dock.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: During the rescue attempt, there were no bodies found.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: According to NATO, a torpedo misfired and detonated a warhead within Kursk.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: It wasn't until September when Russia began operations to retrieve bodies.
author: A2YO837C0O1E91

questionText: The first official announcement of the submarine sinking was made on Aug 14, 2000.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The first Russian rescue attempt to recover the sunk submarine did not begin until Aug 15, 2000.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The Kursk's escape hatch was too badly damaged to dock in 7 attempts in the strong underwater currents.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The Russians gave contradictory reports on the Kursk's status and survival chances.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Russians claimed that the explosion on the submarine was caused by collision with a non-Russian vessel.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Russia's nuclear submarine Kursk fell to the bottom of the Barents Sea while on a training mission.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: The 14,000-ton submarine settled 354 to 450 feet down, trapping 118 sailors.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: Possible causes of the accident were a collision, an onboard explosion, or hitting a WWII mine.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: The only contact with crew, SOS signals tapped on the hull, stopped Tuesday.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: The Russian navy had no advanced rescue vessels so several countries, including the US, offered help.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: On Tuesday it approached NATO about help and by Wednesday accepted British and Norwegian offers.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: Rescue operations ended two days later when divers opened the hatch and found the sub filled with water.
author: A3E3RCR51Z8EVP

questionText: Russia's submarine Kursk sunk on August 12, 2000.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The submarine Kursk weighed 14,000 tons.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The sinking of the Kursk trapped 118 sailors.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The Kursk sunk 354 to 450 feet into the ocean.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Bodies were expected to be recovered from the submarine in October or November.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: Russia rejected an offer from the French government to help with recovery of the submarine.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: There were no survivors on the Kursk.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: The U.S. offered to assist Russia with its recovery efforts.
author: AC5UD8N187QD6

questionText: August 12, 2000, Russia's nuclear submarine Kursk fell to the bottom of the Barents Sea.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E

questionText: The 14,000-ton Kursk settled 354 to 450 feet down, trapping 118 sailors.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E

questionText: The favored Russian explanation for the sinking of the Kursk was a collision.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E

questionText: The only contact with crew of the Kursk was SOS signals tapped on the hull.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E

questionText: 3 days after it sank, there was no further contact with the crew of the Kursk.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E

questionText: Russia approached NATO for help rescuing the sailors trapped on board the Kursk.
author: AEECEMJS22D2E
